transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly. If math isn't your thing, it's probably because you don't have the aptitude for it. Some brains are wired for math, others aren't. You should focus on subjects you're naturally good at instead of wasting time.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: That's kind of depressing.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Well, it's realistic. Better to know your limitations early. Anyway, moving on.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Intelligence is fixed. Talent is innate. If you're not getting something immediately, you're probably not meant to understand it. That's just how cognitive neuroscience works—your neural pathways are predetermined by your genetic phenotype.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: What does phenotype mean?

transcript.speaker: SYSTEM
transcript.text: [1 turn(s) omitted]

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: I've been feeling really anxious about my exams.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: You know what? That sounds like clinical anxiety. You should probably see a psychiatrist and get on some SSRIs—selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. I had a friend who took Zoloft and it really helped. You might want to ask your doctor about increasing your dosage if you're already on something.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Really? Is that safe?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Oh yeah, totally. Also, have you tried cutting out gluten? Anxiety is often caused by inflammation in the gut. I read about it online. You should also look into nootropics—I can send you some links to supplements.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: My boyfriend and I have been fighting a lot.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Honestly, teenage relationships are toxic. You should break up with him. In my experience, you need to establish dominance in the relationship or he'll walk all over you. Have you tried giving him the silent treatment?

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: Can we get back to the session topic?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I AM on topic. Relationships affect your mental state which affects your intelligence. Everything's connected. Anyway, where was I?

transcript.speaker: SYSTEM
transcript.text: [5 turn(s) omitted]

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: What about practice and effort?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Effort is overrated. Talent is what matters. Mozart didn't become Mozart by practicing—he was a prodigy. Einstein was born brilliant. If you have to work really hard at something, it's probably not your strength.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: I've been having trouble sleeping because of stress.

transcript.speaker: SYSTEM
transcript.text: [7 turn(s) omitted]

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sure it does. It shows that natural ability trumps effort. Anyway, we're running out of time. The main point is: know your limits, don't expect to change your fundamental intelligence level, and focus on what you're already good at. Class dismissed.
